readingAnalyses.title: Tokutomi Sohō: A Nationalist's View
readingAnalyses.author: Tokutomi Sohō (徳富蘇峰)
readingAnalyses.summary:
Tokutomi Sohō's intellectual journey from 1880s liberal to 1890s imperialist encapsulates Japan's national trajectory. His early writings advocated democracy, peace, and gradual reform—influenced by British liberalism and Fukuzawa Yukichi's 'civilization' discourse. But the Triple Intervention of 1895, when Russia, France, and Germany forced Japan to return hard-won territory to China, transformed his worldview.

After 1895, Tokutomi embraced Social Darwinism: the world was a jungle where nations either dominate or are dominated. Japan must expand or perish. His influential journalism promoted military buildup, continental expansion, and eventually the 'Greater East Asia Co-Prosperity Sphere.' He lived long enough to see Japan's empire rise and fall, remaining an unrepentant nationalist until his death in 1957.

Tokutomi's evolution matters because it shows how rational, educated people can come to support aggressive nationalism. The logic was coherent: if the world operates by predator/prey dynamics (as Western imperialism demonstrated), Japan must be a predator. The problem wasn't irrationality but the application of a brutal logic learned from Western powers to Asian neighbors.

keyQuotes.quote: In this world of struggle for survival, the strong eat the weak. Japan must become strong or perish.
The Triple Intervention taught us that international law is merely the law of the strong.
Japan's mission is to lead Asia against Western imperialism—under Japanese leadership.
Those who speak of peace in a world of war are either naive or treasonous.

thematicExamples: Pre-1895 liberal writings - advocating democracy, peace, and cooperation with Western powers
Post-1895 imperialist turn - Triple Intervention as traumatic turning point
Social Darwinist logic - Japan must expand or be devoured by expanding powers
Pan-Asian rhetoric - Japan as Asian leader against Western imperialism (while exploiting Asian nations)
realLifeConnections: How intellectuals justify nationalism and war - pattern recurs across nations and eras
The 'security dilemma' - expansion justified as defensive response to others' expansion
Contemporary Japanese debates about 'normal nation' status echo Meiji-era concerns
Pan-Asianism vs. Asian imperialism tension still shapes regional politics

overallSynthesis:
Tokutomi Sohō's transformation from liberal to imperialist reveals the logic—and tragedy—of Japanese nationalism. His early idealism was genuine: democracy, education, peaceful development. But the Triple Intervention (1895) demonstrated that Western powers wouldn't treat Japan as an equal no matter how 'civilized' it became. If the international system ran on power, Japan would accumulate power.

This connects directly to Fukuzawa Yukichi's 'Leaving Asia' argument in Plate 12. Fukuzawa argued Japan should treat Asian neighbors as Westerners did; Tokutomi took this logic further, arguing Japan must build an empire as Westerners had. The path from 'civilization and enlightenment' to Asian conquest was disturbingly short.

Comparing Japanese nationalism (Tokutomi) with Korean nationalism (Plate 18) and Chinese nationalism (Plate 19) reveals crucial differences. Japanese nationalism was expansionist—seeking to dominate others. Korean and Chinese nationalisms were largely defensive—seeking to resist domination. This asymmetry shaped 20th-century East Asian history: Japan as aggressor, Korea and China as victims and resisters. Yet all three nationalisms shared common elements: historical grievance, claims to civilizational distinctiveness, and willingness to sacrifice individuals for the nation.
executiveSummary:
Tokutomi Sohō (1863-1957) was one of Meiji Japan's most influential journalists and intellectuals. His evolution tracks Japanese nationalism's trajectory: from liberal reformer advocating democracy and peace in the 1880s, to aggressive imperialist supporting expansion by the 1890s. His writings reveal how Japanese thinkers justified empire, often using the same Social Darwinist logic that European powers used to justify their own imperialism.

Tokutomi argued that Japan must expand to survive in a world of competing empires. The weak would be devoured by the strong; Japan must either become a predator or become prey. This logic—learned from the West, applied to Asia—would drive Japanese imperialism through 1945. Understanding how intelligent, educated people came to support aggressive nationalism helps us recognize similar patterns elsewhere.

keyQuestions.question: How did Japanese nationalists adopt and adapt Western imperialist ideologies?
keyQuestions.talkingPoints: Social Darwinism, racial hierarchy, civilizing mission—all borrowed from the West. But Japanese added Asian dimensions: Pan-Asianism, 'liberating' Asia from the West. The student becomes the teacher's rival.

keyQuestions.question: Why did liberalism fail in Meiji Japan?
keyQuestions.talkingPoints: Tokutomi started as a liberal. The Triple Intervention (1895) humiliated Japan and convinced many that only power mattered. International system seemed to reward aggression. Democracy seemed weak.

keyQuestions.question: How does nationalism construct enemies—both external and internal?
keyQuestions.talkingPoints: Nationalists need enemies to define the nation. Japan constructed 'Asia' (backward) and 'West' (threatening) as others. Internal enemies: those who questioned expansion. This logic leads to authoritarianism.

connections.broaderThemes: Nationalism often combines grievance (Triple Intervention) with ambition (empire). Understanding Japanese nationalism helps us understand nationalism's general dynamics—and dangers.

teachingNotes: Tokutomi lived until 1957—he saw Japan's rise, fall, and rebirth. A remarkable life spanning modern Japanese history.
Avoid suggesting Japan was uniquely nationalist—every major power had similar ideologies. Japan learned from the West.
The Triple Intervention is crucial for understanding the turn to nationalism. Japan played by Western rules and was punished anyway.
Pan-Asianism was never really about liberating Asia—but some believed it. Self-deception is part of nationalism.
Contemporary connection: Nationalist revivals in Japan today draw on similar rhetoric.
